labeled_chunks.chunk_text: Hi: Newly disabled (use a cane presently) and at a loss for planning vacations for my family, all of whom eat vegan. Prefer domestic travel to start. Any recommendations?

Looking for accessible stuff to do in Charleston. We will be close to Daniel Island. We like the beaches, Looking to rent/use beach chair. What other cool stuff is accessible and avilable that tourists don‚Äôt know about?

My name is Mark. I am 51 years old Marine Veteran I got paralyzed from the Covid vaccine second shot on September 5, 2021. I had taken the second shot Moderna on September 3. At the time I was in peak shape. I was taking a shower, I put my head down I went numb from toe to neck. I initially could only move my head. Now, I can talk, move my arms, not fingers everything else paralyzed neck down, but I have a stand up wheelchair to get around and I bought a 50lb hoyer to travel with. Before paralyzation traveled 300 days a year for 10
plus years. Since I haven‚Äôt. I hope to start traveling this new year.

We‚Äôll be in Quito for 2 nights before heading home next week and would like to stay in the Historic District in a nice hotel. I‚Äôve been scouring the typical search sites (booking.com, kayak, Trivago, etc) and oddly none of them seem to have the filter (that I know I‚Äôve seen/used before) present for ‚Äúelevator‚Äù when searching Quito. Definitely in need of some 1st hand intel. Anywho‚Ä¶ I am in a wheelchair and although we can manage a flight of steps here or there, being that it‚Äôs at the end of our trip, it would be great to find somewhere with an elevator or ground floor rooms (and
little to no other steps necessary to get into/around the building). Our max budget is around $130/nt. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

From a member of our community: I have a spinal cord injury where I can stand or sit for very limited amounts of time. I am trying to research transportation options where I can lay flat whether by air travel or car rides with a paid driver. In the past, I have bought 3 airline seats in order to lay down on certain routes, mainly Southwest, but wondering if anyone has advice here. Can anyone recommend domestic airlines that allow you to lay flat (probably only business or first class), or transportation companies you can hire for long rides where you can lay down? Thanks everyone!

Hi, I was recently put into a Powerchair/wheelchair and am traveling for the first time in years. Due to a mix up, no transport was set up for me to get from the airport (Reagan DCA) to the hotel (Yotel DC) and back again, after the stay. I‚Äôm traveling Oct 19, 2021 thru Oct 21, 2021. If anyone has any experience with this and /or could possibly suggest a company I could call to get this set up, it would be very much appreciated. I‚Äôve never used a wheelchair before (well, not all the time anyway) and am still getting used to it.I plan on using an overnight
bag, as a carry on and will hold it in my lap. Looking for my owners manual, I think I might have to remove the batteries‚Ä¶but wanted to get this posted. üòä Thank you very much for any help!

The New Premier Caribbean Hotel for Wheelchair Accessible Travelers has now opened in St. Maarten The Morgan Resort & Spa - St Maarten Luxury ResortMy husband and I were lucky enough to get to be the very first wheelchair guests at the new Morgan Hotel this past May and we were in love at first sight. From the moment you arrive at the property you know you have arrived somewhere very special as you pass through two sets of gates and guard houses before reaching the glamorous front of the hotel; where the amazingly friendly valet/door-people will help you out of your vehicle. Whether it‚Äôs helping to assemble

back your manual wheelchair or safely unloading a power wheelchair, the staff was obviously trained well as to how to best assist us wheeled travelers. (They will even help carry every last piece of equipment you may have traveled with; and we brought a lot)As you enter the glamorous but modestly sized lobby, you can‚Äôt help but take your eyes off of the giant, gorgeous infinity pool overlooking the ocean that‚Äôs just on the other side of the lobby(*Will come back to the pool in a sec). The amazing front desk staff and concierge will not only help you get checked in, but will personally escort you to

your room to help orient you with the hotel amenities and make sure you have everything you need while settling in (ask for Arielle; she‚Äôs phenomenal). After taking some time to explore the giant accessible room and attached living room, I noticed how they remembered all the little details that are most important to us accessible travelers: lowered closets, electrical controls all within reach, access to the entire room; accessible bathroom with roll under sink, safety toilet (with good amount of grab bars), roll-in shower (flip down benches on order to replace shower chairs); handheld+waterfall shower heads; as well as having the coffee machine, safe and fridge within

reachable zone.Honestly I was blown away by how much they got right with the room; especially after staying at some insane nightmare hotels in the caribbean that claimed to be accessible prior to booking the room. Whoever designed this hotel really took the time to plan out what was needed for their 9 (yes I said 9) accessible rooms and oceanfront suites. What impressed me even more, was the General Manager (Saul) took the time to sit down with us to get some feedback about how we were finding the accessible features of the hotel; and took the time to walk around the property and room with us

and his builder to see what else could be improved on as they were finishing up the property. (Which was not much at all. Just some little stuff like a lower peep hole for the door, changing the bathroom door handle to add a few inches of entry area and changing from shower seats to benches for safety).Just like many hotels where we try to give some critical feedback on the accessibility of the property, they could have just humored us and pretended to care; but no, not these folks. They truly seem to be concerned about making the changes ASAP so that ALL guests get the chance

to enjoy their property equally. That‚Äôs not something you find often in any hotel; let alone a hotel in the Carribean. They even are ordering some beach wheelchairs to use for the pool and maybe even the neighboring beaches. (They can even rent you a beach wheelchair from a local company to be able to take to the other beaches on the island who will bring the chair right to you at that beach and come back at the end of the day for it).Now speaking of their fabulous pool. Never in my life have I seen such a large pool with zero-degree entry going around the entire

sides of this football field sized pool. (There is a regular entry point of the pool too if that‚Äôs easier). You‚Äôll never want to get out of this pool and you probably won‚Äôt need to since the fantastic pool staff bring you anything you need and the bar in the water will fulfill all your cocktail and food fantasies. What I loved was the fact they had these soft pool chairs surrounding the pool (1‚Äô away) that I could easily pull myself out of the water and right into the chair from. The only negative I will say about any of this is the fact that they put

the hot tub in the middle of the pool with no other entry point and you have to go up stairs and down stairs to switch bodies of water. There also is a really cool swim in a cave in the corner with a built in waterslide; but no way to get to the top of the slide if your legs don‚Äôt work (not that my spine Dr. would appreciate me trying slides‚Ä¶lol).If you can drag yourself away from the pool, you must try the restaurant and bar. Chef David will BLOW YOUR MIND with his food. He hit it out of the park on his first try

with the opening menu for the hotel. My spouse couldn‚Äôt stop raving about the Lobster and the Seafood Paella and I was obsessed with the vegetarian items on the menu; especially the Empanadas (They even serve an Impossible burger; which is so hard to find in St. Maarten). Every single thing we tried for breakfast was delicious and will fill you up well for your busy day on the island. Try the fruit and bread platter if you can or the pancakes will have you licking the plate. Or if you don;t feel like dining, try out the bar and let the Bartender Nigel make you one of

his enticing cocktails (let alone he‚Äôs the nicest guy to talk to on the island).I wish I could list every single person who went out of their way to take care of our every need at the hotel; but it would add an entire page to this review. Let‚Äôs just say I can‚Äôt say one negative thing about any of the employees at the hotel. They all made us feel so welcome and treated us as if we were visiting their own home. Leaving was the most difficult part of our entire visit at the hotel. We spent two life changing weeks at the Morgan and tried out

every aspect of that resort and they passed every test we threw at them. There are very few hotels I have ever fallen in love with, but this one definitely moved into my heart for life and I can‚Äôt wait to return. (Or move to the island‚Ä¶ that is how much they made us fall in love with St. Maarten here) Please trust me, you won‚Äôt be disappointed and you‚Äôve never enjoyed yourself more on vacation till you stay here. (You don‚Äôt even have to have a wheelchair to have as good of a time as us).

Hello everyone. My name is Diane Wildowsky and my friend and I have started a new website/blog helping people navigate NYC using a mobility scooter. I include wheelchairs where I can. I ride the subway and buses almost daily with my scooter. And while a restroom might be marked ‚Äúaccessible,‚Äù you learn very quickly, it isn‚Äôt always accessible for everyone. Look forward to meeting you all and happy to answer questions. Thank you in advance for taking time to look at our site. Paint the Town Mobile Paint the Town Mobile

I‚Äôm looking for a three-bedroom house or condo near or on a beach in close proximity to Kailua/Kona that is totally wheelchair accessible with a roll in shower. I‚Äôm familiar with availability for accessible public transportation but would like the option of renting a lift equipped vehicle as well. Hi everyone! I am from Sacramento, California, I am 65 years young, been on a wheelchair since 2015 and I happen to get a Atto scooter that helps me move around every now and then.. I love exploring the world ‚Ä¶

Thing to see and do in following ports My husband and I are scheduled to take a Caribbean cruise in March 2024. We both travel in Prides scooters, which makes booking accessible excursions with the ship most impossible. We enjoy getting off the ship and do sightseeing around the port of call. We will be in the following ports and would like to suggestions of we things we might do and/or see in the following ports: St. Maarten , Antigua, St. Kitts, Tortola, BVI, Martinique, St. Lucia, Dominica, and Grand Turk, Turks & Caicos Thank you to everyone who reads our request even if you can‚Äôt or don‚Äôt
respond. If you do an extra special thank you.

Hello and good afternoon! My name is Karen and I am a 59 year old plus sized woman (currently 305 lbs coming down from originally being 430 lbs). I currently own a Pride Victory 10 mobility scooter because at the time I got it (5 years ago) that was the only mobility scooter Medicare would cover (at 80%) for a person weighing over 430 pounds. I would be very grateful on any advice/opinions any of you have on folding wheelchairs. Being as I have had my mobility scooter for quite a few years now, it is time to get something new again. Do I get another scooter, do

I get a power wheelchair, or do I get one of those plus a folding wheelchair??? All decisions I need to make and would sure appreciate your input. I do not own and cannot afford to buy a vehicle with a lift (on SSDI with very limited income), so I got ADA certified and ride a paratransit bus that has a lift here in Phoenix, Az to my doctors appointments, pharmacy, etc‚Ä¶.The problem is I have no social life, or way to go out to do anything fun like out to dinner with friends, going to a mall, craft fairs, visit friends houses etc because paratransit will not

take me to anywhere other than medically related places. I did not know about folding wheelchairs until just recently. It folds up, I can put it in the trunk of a friends vehicle, put it in the trunk of a Uber‚Ä¶..I could actually go places and do things again!! Plus just on a side note in case this helps someone else decide on a scooter‚Ä¶my Pride Victory 10 has been wonderful, very relaible, never a problem. However it is big, wide, heavy even broken down into pieces, and longer than most other scooters because it is a bariatric sized scooter as well. It for sure causes issues at

times because of the turning radius, space in restaurants, it‚Äôs longer than most street vans with ramps up the back can usually fit. Allll of that being said (whew!!) what do you all think of FOLDING wheelchairs? It would still have to be for a plus sized me, so I would need a weight capacity over 305 lbs. Are they comfortable, relaible, can I even lift one by myself or would I need constant help to be able to use it by myself? Brand names you recommend and why?? Sorry for the book, I just wanted to tell you as much as I could so you could know
what I would need better maybe??? Any information or suggestions would be very much appreciated. Thank you and have a great day! Karen

We finally went, we stayed for a whole week. My daughter with multiple disabilities, autism intellectually delayed and others had the best time of her life. What a super great birthday. What Disney World is handicap accessible however I did have a hard time navigating in Universal Studios. Definitely need two. Good pair of walking shoes day three red wheelchair and my oldest did push me around everywhere we went. The staff is very helpful. Very understanding and compassionate. The characters are very awesome with the kids and adults with disabilities, we stayed at the Drury Plaza Hotel in Orlando Disney Which we had a good time we

had a blessed they have shadows to take you to and from all Disney theme parks and yes, it is very accessible for people in wheelchairs. They even ask you if you need the tamp down if they see you have issues with walking, they saw that I was blinding hand mobility issue so they asked if I wanted the wrap down even though I was not in a wheelchair no trouble airport they were very helpful. My daughter had a Great time my oldest had fun with the fast pass cus we didn‚Äôt have too wait in long lines lol going off peak season is great cus
1 less people 2 shorter lines for rides 3 just overall a lot better for people with disabilities, especially if they are autistic

I‚Äôve thought about getting a 3‚Äù raised commode seat that could be used in hotels during travel, but it would be big and cumbersome‚Äîplus stability is questionable??? Hi there. Has anyone stayed in Reykjavik and had a hotel which actually met your needs? I am struggling to find a room with toilet grab bars, let alone a decent bed height for transferring. Thank you!

I want to share info about a trip my husband & I just took to Texas. I have a Pride Baja scooter & several places we wanted to go were accessible for my scooter! We visited the Waco Mammoth National Monument & all the trails & the dig site were easy for me to navigate. Pretty exciting to see actual mammoth bones! We went to Cameron Park & there were many trails for my scooter & my husband‚Äôs bike. The bridge over the Brazos River was scooter friendly, too. We spent a couple days in Austin after leaving Waco. We stayed at the Lakeway Resort & Spa on

Travis Lake. The room had a lovely view of the Lake & we even saw a doe & 2 fawns in the wilderness below our balcony. The bathroom was spacious & had a low tub with plenty of grab bars & a slide bar for the shower head. The only problem was that the bed was extra high, so somewhat difficult to get up onto. Lots of wide open spaces & a beautiful place. Visited Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center. The trails were either cemented or pea gravel. Lots of shady spots to get out of the sun if needed. The gift shop was large & spacious, plenty

of room for scooter to navigate. Also hit the Roy & Ann Butler Hike & Bike Trail, a waterfront trail loop around Lady Bird Lake. It was also pavement & pea gravel all around. Hope this helps anyone with TX tourist ideas!üíô

My first trip after the amputation 2 years ago then a stroke in Feb 2023 was a solo trip to Bogota, I had never even been out of the country before and had just got my first passport,, I am Glad I chose Alaska and American Airlines, called their disability phone lines, they even moved my seats closer to the front even though they did not show available when I was picking my seats, I told them of my condition and that I was fearful of getting lost in the airports even though I gave myself 3 hour layovers, and living in the mountains most of my life,,

they gate checked my chair so it was waiting at the next stop, they escort me to my next gate (via a train - another first) . they helped me thru customs on both ends and helped me transfer my bags and at the destination they got them at baggage claim took them to the hotel shuttle area and waited with me,, they were all Angels in my eyes. That was May 2023, since then I traveled to Texas and back and now less than 2 weeks from leaving to return to Colombia to spend the winter there for 6 months. My advice is get out there and
Live and Enjoy yourself

My husband watched the 1956 Moby Dick with Gregory Peck and said ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs have a Moby Dick weekend in New Bedford‚Äù and we did. He is a full-time wheelchair user, only able to use his right side. We have recently ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù from Hoyer lift to slide board transfers wheelchair ‚Üê> bed, and that makes finding a hotel easier. It was a wonderful trip with no ‚Äúsurprises‚Äù. Hotel: Fairfield Inn at Marriott. ADA room with 2 queens. I called the hotel directly 2 days before arrival and Jaz at the front desk was very helpful. She measured top of bed height (24‚Äù) which made for a pretty level transfer.

I explained that getting out of bed would require backing the wheelchair up to the headboard, so any nightstand must be movable. The left-hand bed did not have a nightstand on the left so that worked. I also asked for bathroom grab bars to be on the right, and she double checked that our room had that config. When we arrived, everything was as specified. My husband and I did not need assistance, but I saw our check-in person Mallory helping a couple with mobility issues load their bags on a dolly. Free breakfast was a better than average self-serve. I served my husband, but there was staff

refilling food and I bet they would help someone if asked. Activities: Harbor-walk: beautiful, wide 1.5 mile walkway along the water. Made of large concrete sidewalk slabs and the transitions, while pretty good, were still painful for my husband. Whaling museum: A great museum. You could spend a whole day there. Roomy elevators to all floors, even the observation deck. The only thing inaccessible is climbing into the whaling ship model. I took the highlights tour (even though my husband chose not to) and it was also accessible. Fort Tabor: Lots of paved paths around the fort and by the water. Totally smooth sailing. Walking: Historic center roads

are cobblestones, uncomfortable even in a car. Sidewalks are slate, which wasn‚Äôt too bad, and crosswalks are slate. I managed to find street or lot parking everywhere. I took a guided whaling themed walking tour for an hour while my husband sat on the whaling museum patio, but the walk covered just one city block and we did not enter buildings, so it would have been possible in a wheelchair. Restaurants:All were accessible and people went out of their way to be helpful. Antonio‚Äôs: They put out a ramp so the wheelchair could climb the one step to get in. There was room to navigate to a table.

Tia Maria‚Äôs: We ate outdoors at a table. We loved the food and went twice. Lots of authentic Portuguese faire. Indoors would not be accessible. Black Whale: Large parking lot, easy ramp, lots of roomy table choices. Coastal Bubbles Wine Bar: On my walk I saw a lovely deck with the sign ‚ÄúSip, slurp, Sundays. Oysters $2‚Äù. The deck was up a flight of stairs, but the manager showed me that entering at the back of the restaurant was street level. Best oysters of the summer. Lovely fall weather and a great trip. I recommend it.
I‚Äôm flying to Colorado for a MS bike adventure. I have a scooter that folds up nicely. How do I put it on the plane? What do I need to do with the airline? Thanks for any help!

Hi guys - as a service, accessibleGO is currently focused on American/domestic travel, but I couldn‚Äôt resist sharing these very cool international travel opportunity that somebody shared with us recently. If any of you have ever had a safari on your bucket list, this might be a game-changer. üôÇ Ximuwu Lodge is a new, wheelchair-friendly lodge located in South Africa, on the border of Kruger National Park. Their representative describes their offering as: Our lodge, located in the greater kruger, is designed specifically to accommodate guests with mobility challenges, with a range of wheelchair-friendly features throughout the property. Our gameviewer, shuttle bus, bar, spa, photographic hides, boma, and

all other amenities are fully accessible, ensuring that guests with mobility challenges can enjoy every aspect of their stay. In addition to being wheelchair-friendly, our lodge is also exclusive use, offering guests a private and luxurious experience that is unmatched in the region. We believe that this combination of accessibility and exclusivity makes our lodge an ideal choice for travelers who are looking for a unique and unforgettable experience. Thought you guys might appreciate! Sounds like an exciting experience.

I am Que. I have severe osteoarthritis in both hips and my right ankle due to a bizarre accident 50 years ago.I spent a year on crutches, with all my weight on my left leg, then another year using a cane. this was in 1974 and 1975. when the Pandemic started my Y closed and I didn‚Äôt keep up with my exercise routine.I have become increasingly disabled over the years, finding various helps when I needed them. I now use one ski walking pole and one Strong Arm. I am looking at getting either an electric wheelchair or a scooter for traveling as I am super slow when

walking and my hip starts hurting after walking about a block. I understand from reading these posts that Viator has good accessible tours. are there accessible boat tours? the other times my wife and I have traveled in Europe we have taken boat tours of the canals and rivers but some of them were really hard for me to get to with one cane. I don‚Äôt think I could go down the stairs or clamber around a boat now.

My oldest has Cerebral Palsy and utilizes a power wheelchair. My husband is having second thoughts because of this. Might you have any suggestions and tips to help encourage us? I‚Äôm thinking this will be one of her few, or only, opportunities to travel abroad. Thanks for your help!

Am a below knee amputee with prosthetic leg planning a cruise to the Antarctic. Am over 70 and active only need a walk-in shower in my cabin vs a full ADA cabin. Interested if any recommendations for a cruise line with excursions that I can manage. Will not walk on ice but can ride zodiacs. Like Silver Seas. Any suggestions?

I‚Äôm just back from a three week, six country vacation in Europe. As a person with a spinal cord injury who cannot stand/walk, the past 35 years of air travel has been extremely frustrating and sometimes physically painful. I always come home saying I never want to stop traveling, but I wish, just once, the air travel would go smoothly. Well this time was oh so close! Nearly as perfect as it could get. I fly United out of O‚ÄôHare a number of times per year. In comparing O‚ÄôHare against most of the European airports I‚Äôve been through, it has always provided the least attention to me as

a wheelchair user. This time, something was different. More special treatment, a specific line at customs, and better trained personnel from the agents to the lift assistants. What, Finally?? It would have been an absolutely mind blowing experience had my chair been at the plane door when I arrived back in Chicago. The agent said I‚Äôd have to go to baggage claim to get it. Knowing my rights, I said my chair must be delivered to the door. (Ok, technically ‚Äúas close to the door as possible‚Äù). Funny, within literally seconds, my chair appeared. What? OK. That was it. The attendant wheeled me through the wheelchair line at

customs and we were out the door. Just wanted to share. Hope this is the start of a trend. ü§û For the trip we flew into Amsterdam and out of Zurich. I splurged and hired a driver for the Netherlands and Belgium where we attended the Fomula 1 Dutch Grand Prix practice day and visited a few WWI & II memorial sites. I set up the hotels and sites on my own for this part of the trip. Then we made our way to France where we met some friends and hired the Claire & George Foundation (C&G)based in Bern Switzerland to drive us through Luxembourg, Germany, and

Switzerland. C&G provided a driver, set up all accessible hotels, and any attraction and event tickets for us They even arranged a hoyer lift for me to be delivered to our hotels It was a wonderful, stress-free trip that included the Mosel Wine festival and a Champaign region tour I highly recommend C&G. They are easy to work with and can help plan the type of travel you like. Last year they set up a mostly train tour of Switzerland for us. After all the years of setting up my own travel, it was nice to have someone else do the work. Now, if they could only take
care of those cobblestones‚Ä¶ Happy to share locations and hotels. Just ask. ~Wendy

Anyone here who flies frequently notice an increase in the number of passengers who are taking advantage the pre-board option? The gate agents are always really good about getting me on first but there is always a line of at least ten other ‚Äúdisabled‚Äù people jockeying for position behind me and giving me dirty looks because I get to board first. What‚Äôs amazing is

that the majority of them are all ambulatory and walk down the jetway without any assistance at all and when we get to our destination pop right up and sprint out the plane.Am I wrong in being totally annoyed with this or is it just my imagination that this seems to be happening more and more. I also fly other airlines that have assigned seats and I never see the number of pre-boarders that I do when I fly Southwest. I understand that there are a lot of peoples who need assistance to get through the terminals to the gates because of the distances involved but to then

I would prefer to write a complete review of this hotel after my stay, but my experience with Hyatt while trying to make reservations has been nothing less than miserable. My husband and I are planning to attend a conference in July 2024 that will be held at the Hyatt Buffalo. After registering for the conference, I followed the instructions on the conference website and attempted to make reservations for two rooms at the special conference rate. I reserved both an accessible room with a roll-in shower for my husband and myself (an amputee and wheelchair user) and a standard room for my aide. While I had no

problem making a reservation for my aide at the conference rate, I was told by the Hyatt reservation agent that I would be charged nearly double for the accessible room because there were no accessible rooms within the conference room block. I contacted one of the conference planners to request assistance in getting both rooms at the conference rate. During the contract process, he explained, the conference planners were told by Hyatt sales staff it was impossible to contract for accessible rooms as they needed to be made available to all Hyatt customers. While this is a nice thought, it is just not true. This conference, and others

like it are held annually. It is the custom of the meeting planners to make sure that there are accessible rooms available within the room block as there is a large percentage of individuals with disabilities who attend the conference, and they require accessible rooms. Attendees of this conference in previous years are surveyed about their need for accessible rooms so the planners can ensure that an appropriate number of rooms are available in subsequent years. I contacted Hyatt Global Customer Care Center. I was told I could not have an accessible room at the conference rate as the room block was sold out. So why could I

confirm a standard room for my aide at the conference rate? The practice of charging one rate for a standard room and a higher rate for an accessible room is blatant discrimination, and a violation of the Americans With Disabilities Act and, I imagine, any number of state and federal laws designed to enhance interstate commerce and to prevent similar acts of prejudice. Hyatt Hotels should be ashamed.

I recently flew from Eugene Oregon to Seattle Washington on an Embraer ERJ 175 Alaska Airline in which I made reservations months in advance. Three days before I traveled I received a call confirming my power wheelchair and that it was to be gate checked and put in the only slot on the airline for power wheelchairs. Upon arrival at the airport, after checking in for my flight, I was told that my power wheelchair, which is 36 inches in total height, was too tall to fit on the aircraft. I have a tilt function, which I tilted back so that the hand grips were no higher than

33 inches, and was told that this was sufficient to fit on the aircraft. After we boarded and the plane was ready to take off, the cargo personnel came on the airplane to tell me that my power wheelchair would not fit on the airplane. I was told I had two options, one was to continue on with this flight and my power wheelchair would arrive with any luck later that evening as my destination was Washington DC and my second choice was I could be taken off the airplane yet there were no other flights out that day and they could not confirm there was even one

the next day that could get us to Washington DC. I continue on with our travels and made it to Washington DC on the flights that we had reserved months in advance, and my power wheelchair arrived the next day at 11 AM. On return flight we have the similar plane from Seattle to Eugene and experienced the same problem, only this time my power wheelchair did not arrive at my home until a day and a half later. The bottom line is make sure that you do not fly with a power wheelchair that has a total height no greater than 33 inches on an Embraer ERJ

175 aircraft. Alaska airline I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs not the only airline that utilizes this style of airplane. So please do your homework so you do not experience the same headaches and disruption to your vacation that we did.

Hi, I'm Pam, a proud Disney Adult! I completed an internship at Walt Disney World through Disney University, worked there for a few years, and am now a religious vlog watcher and travel agent! You would think that I would've known all that there is to know about Walt Disney World with that resume, but it wasn't until I traveled with family and friends with disabilities that I learned first-hand about accessible travel. To me, being a true ally to the disabled community is learning from their lived experiences, so I am grateful that I now have this knowledge to pass on along with all of my other

tips and tricks! Walt Disney World is beloved for many reasons, and one of those is its vast options of accessible activities. I recommend reading the descriptions of the rides online ahead of time to see which ones not only seem accessible for you, but are experiences that you would enjoy! Some rides you can stay in a power wheelchair, while others require a transfer. Some rides have specific seats for those needing to transfer. One example is the brand new Tron ride at Magic Kingdom. The standard seat looks similar to a motorcycle, but there is a "caboose" in the back that is an accessible seat. If

you are capable of transferring, one thing that I learned is that when the cast members (workers) ask "can you transfer?" first ask "what are my options?" One example for this is the Jungle Cruise ride in Magic Kingdom. My friend said that she could transfer and she did. The steepness of the stairs getting into and out of the ride were more steep than she thought. My daughter and I ended up helping her quite a bit, which we were happy to do, but we found out after that there was an accessible boat where she could have stayed in a wheelchair! Another great option is the

Disability Access Pass (DAS) which is intended for guests who have difficulty tolerating extended waits in a conventional queue environment due to a disability. This pass allows guests to request a return time for a specific experience that is comparable to the current standby wait. This feature permits guests using the DAS to enjoy other experiences in the park instead of physically waiting in the standby line. Guests can register in person or pre-register via live video call (the guest with a disability must be present) and use DAS Advance pre-arrival planning. It is most convenient to use the DAS on the My Disney Experience app which is

available for smart phones. This app has so many great features. Besides the DAS, two that are very helpful are the listed updated wait times and the ability to pre-order quick service food. Speaking of planning ahead, while there are wheelchairs and mobility scooters available to rent (for a fee) at the parks, it is much more economical and efficient to rent through an outside company. When mobility aids are rented through the park, they have to stay in the park. Renting through an outside company allows you to take the wheelchair or scooter anywhere. Some of the resorts at Walt Disney World are huge, so the walk

from the hotel to the bus could be very exhausting. A company called Scooterbug is the exclusive provider of mobility devices for Walt Disney World. This distinction is important because they can drop off the scooter at your resort without you being present. With the possibility of flight delays or other mishaps, this service offers great peace of mind. One thing that we learned when asking the front desk for my friend's scooter: if you book through an agent, the device could possibly be under their name. Mobility devices and scooters aren't the only pieces of equipment available for rent (from other companies - Scooterbug only offers wheelchairs,

scooters, and strollers). One example for this is that my friend rented an IV pole for her feeding tube. While enjoying is priority number one, it is also a good idea to know the medical services available ahead of time just in case. AdventHealth is the official healthcare provider of Walt Disney World. They have medical equipment for rent, urgent care services, virtual appointments available 24/7, in-park first aid, and a new full-service emergency room minutes from Walt Disney World. While we never like to think about these things happening on vacation, knowing that these services are conveniently available and accessible provides peace of mind when travelling. Walt

Disney World has accessible room options in all of their hotels. It is important to think about what you need ahead of time so that questions can be asked before booking the room. Some of these questions are the height of the bed and whether you need a powered door to get in and out of the room. Only you know what you need best! Working with a travel agent who has experience in accessible travel can also help you to brainstorm some questions specific to your needs. I could talk about Walt Disney World all day long! If you have any questions, let them in the comments
below and I‚Äôm happy to answer. You can also search and book on accessible GO today!

My name is Danielle and I am a disabled content creator. My channels are called ‚ÄúDaniellevates‚Äù because the content is all about elevating ideas about disability and rare disease. Full-length vlogs feature accessibility reviews from my adventures in Boston and beyond.Short form content consists of series such as Breaking the 4th Wall of Disability, Accessible Design in the Wild, and more! Since birth, I have had an extremely rare technically undiagnosed neuromuscular disease. You can watch & subscribe to me here . This vlog is part two of a day trip from Boston to New York City, and the purpose of the trip was to see "Into the

Woods" on Broadway! This vlog takes us from the outside of the St. James Theatre and to our seats. I now have my own mobility scooter, but during this trip I used a transport chair that I borrowed from my local senior center. While there are many aspects to having a disability that make life more difficult, we have to utilize the advantages when they come our way! Case in point: you can see our group receive the VIP treatment and skip the line to get into the theater safely. I was very pleasantly surprised by the proactive nature of the St. James Theatre. I selected an ADA

seat for myself and an ADA companion seat for my friend, and they emailed me the night before to see if I would like to transfer into one of their seats or stay in my chair. When I indicated that I would be transferring, they said that they would store my chair and bring it back at intermission or anytime that I needed it. I would say that this email is not usual, so definitely plan ahead and ask any questions that you have ahead of time. For someone like myself, sitting in an ADA seat is a must. While I can do stairs with railings, they are

draining and I am dependent on them having railings and not being too steep. Additionally, in an emergency, I would likely be one of the last ones out of the building anyways, so adding stairs as an obstacle is not a good idea. The show was amazing, and the rest of the video shows us dining in Times Square, our Amtrak train ride home (spoiler alert: half of us missed the train!), a recap of the trip and an awkward bathroom mishap, and a celebrity cameo from two comedy legends! Broadway lived up to the hype, and our little day trip was definitely chock-full of New York Moments.

Key Takeaways If you need ADA seating for your health and safety, don't overthink it. Utilize these seats! Think of possible situations ahead of time (seating, bathroom, entering and exiting) and contact the theater with any questions. I should not have waited for them to contact me - this is a rare phenomenon in my experience! If a situation comes up that you didn't think of (like me wanting to get to my seat safely from the dense crowd), don't be afraid to ask for assistance. New York City is crowded. The streets aren't in good condition (I highlight this in part 1 of the NYC Vlogs). Plan

ahead for what mobility aid you might need in these conditions. Make a list weeks before the show of what equipment and supplies that you will need. Add to this list whenever you think of something and pack your bag at least one day before. Once the show starts, be in the moment and enjoy! With all the traveling and hustle and bustle to just get to your seat, it can be hard to unwind. Let yourself take in your surroundings and immerse yourself in the show.

Hello All, my name is Sarah, and I am a multiple sclerosis survivor, mom, army military vet, and Paralyzed Veterans of America board member, so my hands are full. I love to ride my trike because multiple sclerosis is a move-it-or-lose disease, and I refuse to lose anything to the stinky disease. 15 years is long enough to know that MS is a one-star disease that should not be recommended to anybody, but my little boys are my world. I do anything for them, so I do everything I can for them, including camping and hiking and biking, and Team Mom-ing every sport they play. I strive to

keep walking and dream of running again someday with the help of CIONIC sleeves (https://cionic.com/). The VA is putting on both my legs. With all the snow this year, I plan on celebrating my 40th birthday in Mammoth Mountain, learning to sit-ski as I used to be an avid snowboarder before my diagnosis in ‚Äò09.

I just completed a very enjoyable cruise with my family from Anchorage to Vancouver but I must complain about their airline assistance department. I booked 3 staterooms including a suite for my son‚Äôs family and a cabin for my medical aide. We decided to let NCL provide air arrangements, transfer and overnight stay at the Anchorage Hilton for myself, my wife and my aide. The handicapped rooms with roll in shower do not have hand showers! The travel department put my aide on a separate flight from mine for the return journey. I called to change this and was told ‚Äúbecause she did not have the same booking

number as my itinerary there was nothing that they could do until 10 days before the travel date‚Äù even though I said it was not possible for me to travel without my aide! I tried, unsuccessfully, to resolve this sooner but finally 10 days before the flight, the resolution department agreed to put her on my flight at an additional cost of $480 which I reluctantly agreed to. I then contacted Alaska Air handicapped assistance to have my seat move nearer the front of the plane since I require an aisle chair. There I was told I should never have been put on the Vancouver to Seattle leg

of the trip because it was in Embraer 160 plane which is not allowed to carry lithium batteries even in the main cabin. I called NCL travel resolution who said I should have known that it‚Äôs on their website but I pointed out that depending on how you query the mobility section of your website you may or may not be shown the warnings about the Embraer planes. They then rerouted us via Air Canada to our Newark destination. I asked him for my $480 back but they refused.

I really appreciated this candid and loving conversation about traveling with a child who has autism: https://news.delta.com/accessibility-travel-customer-shares-perspective-traveling-autism When we travel, we encounter so many strangers - and this is such a nice reminder that you just never know somebody‚Äôs story and to be kind and patient, as much as you can. I particularly liked this exchange (from the piece linked above) with some practical tips on how to make travel easier: ‚ÄúAllison: Accessibility in travel has come a long way, but we know there is still work to be done. From your perspective, what improvements could Delta and the industry make to our processes that would help your

family? Donna: I was once on a flight with a woman who discreetly handed out notecards to customers that said she had an autistic child with her and to please be patient. I thought it was such a great idea. I know customers can work with Reservations and Airport Customer Service to ensure crews are notified of someone traveling with an invisible disability who may need additional assistance before boarding ‚Äì I think others would benefit from knowing that too. [I‚Äôve often thought that] having a pin or lanyard on for employees who have some experience with autism would be a massive help. It would also serve as
an identifier for customers. I can sit here and tell you all about what to do, but when you have someone who‚Äôs lived it and understands it, that makes a big difference.‚Äù

Just remember while in US the vendor must meet ADA requirements as to accessibility and you as a disabled traveler are entitled to things like accessible bathrooms, hotels, restaurants, attractions such as Disney. BUT, once you leave the geographical boundaries of US, you are no longer pritecby ADA. BEST ADVICE. - PLAN AHEAD Make arrangements early as possible before trip. Work with airlines, cruiselines, etc. Do your research of country you are planning to visit to see if similar law exists ir provisions that country or city has made. I found once we reached some downtown areas in Mexico the sidewalks have curb cuts at each intersection. I

found out the hard way. Make sure you are dead center when going up the curb cut you are approaching fr the next block or you might tip over as I did in the waterfront street in Cozumel. There a half dozen Mexican men sitting on wall smoking but they hopped ss if shot from a cannon, checked on me and helped me stand up and they got my scooter upright. I then realized after granddaughter saw it that I busted center seam of a brand neecpsir of nice slacks from waist band to crotch. First and last time worn as once back in stateriomn l threw them
away as fabric was ruined.

I have been asked to be one of the sites Travel Forum Experts and I must say that I am honored to be chosen to fill this role. A little about myself. I sustained a Spinal Cord Injury in an auto accident back in 1968 when I was four years old and have been using a manual wheelchair to get around ever since. My injury is at the T-12 level which basically means I am totally paralyzed from the waist down. I successfully completed my education up to the Masters degree level and have been working in the field of human services for most of my professional life.

My wife and I live in a semi-rural area outside of Philadelphia Pennsylvania along with our two dogs. I have been lucky enough to be able to travel quite extensively both for leisure and business purposes and have been to a majority of the States in the US and several countries in Central and Northern Europe as well. We have also started cruising and have been on two so far and have one scheduled for April of this year. Bucket list for travel is Southern Europe, Hawaii and Asia, Please feel free to reach out to me with any questions you may have and I will do my
best to answer them. Travel is an amazing thing and I hope everyone can experience it. Cheers!

We just visited the Hilton Resort in Quebec City in Canada after a great cruise. However the hotel is terrible for assessable needs. Even though their website promotes assessable, it is NOT assessable! The only thing included was wide door openings. There was no ADA higher toilet. It was extremely low as if designed for a child. There were no handrails around the toilet either. The shower did not have a chair to sit on. The shower had only one hold bar that was opposite the controls and was under the shower head. You could not reach the hold bar while standing by the water controls. We had

reserved a one bedroom suite and the bed was so wide that you could not ride a wheelchair or rollator to move upward towards the headboard to get onto the bed itself! We were extremely disappointed in this hotel, especially when we were told that all their ‚Äúassessable‚Äù rooms were the same way. I guess Canada has a different attitude toward assessability. At least we would think that Hilton would understand and mandate their hotels to minimum standards. Use caution when reserving rooms in Canada!

I‚Äôve been thinking of a few things that ease travel & thought I‚Äôd share in case others might find them handy. Backstory: Decades ago I temped a lady whose husband had left for work one day & vanished, gone without a trace; ~ 15 years ago I went on business trips with a colleague who gave me this tip; & I watch WAY too much true crime as I‚Äôm convinced that every solo foray leads to instant serial murder. Anyway, every time the coworker left her hotel room she made a brief note giving the time, date, destination, perhaps expected return. It wasn‚Äôt formal or elaborate, just a

casual set of facts that would be invaluably helpful in trying to find her if she did in fact go missing. I don‚Äôt know if anyone else knew; it would be a good safety measure for almost anyone solo, no big deal, just a voice memo with dates & time erased on return or post-it by the phone or on the door that could be tossed on return, no need to involve others (could also add to dr. appt calendar to keep track of mundane things ‚Äî ~ how often to bank, hair color, drycleaner, neighbor‚Äôs dog running loose, whatever(

hi, i have a tip for wheelchair users visiting the UK-but its only useful for those of us with blow up wheels,not rubberised. ill tell you how i found this out, a few years ago, i was using a disabled forum and a user came on explaining that they despratly needed there wheels blowing up and they went into a car/ cycle etc type huge shop/store called HALFORDS. recently,i noticed my wheels were way to soft and low,but there was no leakage,and i typed out to my suport staff about remembering this persons comment from a few years ago. he said lets try it then,so we parked outside

HALFORDS, he went in with my wheelie, and they were absolutely wonderful, they looked for the corect PSI first and then pumped them up, and he also noticed my breaks werent fixed properly so he sorted them out it only needed a bit of movemtn and the guy said come anytime you need it sorting, he woudnt take any money and that is the same lovely atittude the person i saw writing on the forum a few years ago. so ive thought,just in case any of you are ANYWHERE in the UK with a HALFORDS nearby, or even if you live here like me or know someone here
it coud help-its worth going to unless your able to pump them yourself,i know a few people whove bought pumps from TEMU to do there wheels but i dont know how they turned out.i hope this helps. üôÇ

For my 60th birthday year, Chet and I took my dream trip to Japan. We journeyed as far north as Nikko National Park and as far south as Nagasaki. We saw ancient temples and shrines, wild monkeys, amazing forests, and interesting museums. We ate at 7 11, Family Mart and Lawson convenience stores, restaurants, and local markets. We dipped our toes in the Japan Sea, climbed sand dunes, and even rode a camel. We traveled in a Mini Wink camper van from Japan Campers for three weeks, driving up and down crazy mountain roads, driving through rice paddies, and in the city traffic of Toyoko and Osaka. We

camped at Michi No Eki roadside stops and other stops recommended by the Japan Campers app. We hope you will join us on this trip of a lifetime. We had a blast, and I hope you will enjoy joining us through this video series. We also lightly discuss accessibility that we see in our journey. This episode starts our journey from Japan Campers Narita, Japan to Nikko National Park. We spent the morning traveling pass beautiful places including rice fields, forests, stream, and small towns, and spent the afternoon starting our exploration of Nikko National Park. We are Betsy and Chet, and our oldest son, Alex. For 33

years, we thought Alex, had nonverbal autism, intellectual disability, ADHD, but a few years ago we found out that he has Phelan McDermid. Alex goes on many trips with us, but this time the plane trip is too far. Part of the reason we make these videos is to share the world with Alex and others who are unable to make a journey to Japan. We have no idea what Alex understands receptively, so videos are a way to visually communicate where we went for three weeks. He likes to use his eye gaze communication device to watch his vacation videos so now in a way he can

see Japan with us. Our videos, Goal 1: Joyful Life are based on our family's journey and strategies we use to improve the quality of our life through meaningful leisure experiences. It is our hope to reach our number one goal of having a joyful life and to help others reach that goal too. We are hoping that our videos will encourage everyone to get out and have fun.

The accessibleGO community forum is where travelers with accessible needs gather to make new friends while they share tips, recommendations, and resources. Every day there are great conversations, and each week we‚Äôll share some of our favorite highlights. Question : Who are the best, most reliable REGIONAL accessible van rental companies? MobilityWorks was a big winner for our community. They offer regional rentals across the US. According to their website, ‚ÄúMobilityWorks offers wheelchair accessible van rentals to help you decide which accessible vehicle fits your needs. We also have wheelchair van rentals available to help you with occasional transportation needs ‚Äî locally or nationwide. You can rent for

a day, a weekend, or longer.‚Äù Wdavidstone shares: ‚ÄúI have had a positive experience with MobilityWorks in Nashville, TN. I think they are probably the only option here. I talked to them in the past 2 weeks and they are currently totally booked for July. I have also had a positive experience in Atlanta with AMS Vans.‚Äù Charliemitts recommends: ‚ÄúWe recently used MobilityWorks in San Diego. Was a wonderful experience. They now have it set where you can pick and drop off at the airport. Mobility Works is s nationwide franchise that it is in most major cities. ‚Äú Patty Mayer also had a positive experience: ‚Äú MobilityWorks

in San Diego CA has been very accommodating for us. Nice vans. Call ahead and reserve. They are currently trying to have their rentals right at the airport but had not been approved to do so as of April 1, 2023. We needed to get a wheelchair service to transport us to and from from airport to MW, which was very good but pricey on top of renting too.‚Äù United Access also got several votes. Jstorky1 shares: ‚ÄúUnited Access in Portland Oregon near the airport was good. I have been disappointed in the quality of vans we rented at Wheelers in Seattle. Got an old dented white van,

my wife used the grab strap on the ceiling to get into the van and it pulled off and we had to pay for tge whole cost of repair. Some of the vans we rented in Maui had service lights lit up on the dash and bald tires. The proximity to the airport was the main reason we used Wheelers. They have pretty much a monopoly in Hawaii. I haven‚Äôt tried other companies in Seattle.‚Äù AMS Vans got a shout-out, as well. They serve the Atlanta Phoenix, Houston, Cincinnati, and New Jersey areas. Atlanta - 800-775-8267 As did Wheelers , who bill themselves as ‚ÄúYour go to resource
for daily, weekly, weekend, and monthly handicap van rentals".‚Äù Is there a regional van rental service you‚Äôve used? Sound off in the comments below. We‚Äôll keep updating the list for all to use.

Looking for a travel companion. Must pay your own way. I live in kansas and have a electric wheel chair and hate to be alone. I‚Äôm a widower, live alone. And ready to get out out and about. Please get a hold of me if interested. Open to all parts of the country. Mark L.

We had originally planned a one night stay in Vienna on the way from Krakow to Munich. But we chose to leave Krakow early because of it was not for wheelchair users. We forgot to factor in that Vienna is super busy because of the Christmas markets there. So I went hunting for a hotel. Vienna was booked solid. I finally went to sleep at midnight with no reservations. I woke at 7 a.m. and checked again. There was a hotel, near the train station, that had an open room. I booked it and we departed Krakow. *Be sure to check carefully what train station you are arriving

and departing from, there are many. We arrive and find the Prizeotel by Radisson about a block from the train station. Easy to walk to. It was clean, efficient, and very wheelchair friendly. The only bad thing I can say about it is that it didn‚Äôt have an in-room coffee maker, but you could buy some in the lobby. Bed height was perfect, the shower was amazing, the staff great, very reasonable compared to other hotels. For years Paris has been my favorite city. Move over Paris, with Vienna‚Äôs wheelchair accessible subway, trams and buses I think I have a new favorite. The architecture is stunning. The people

were friendly. The museums were mostly accessible. The Christmas markets are each different and beautiful (also packed). We visited the Belvedere Place to see the Klimt exhibit and the Military museum. Mostly we wandered around muttering ooohhh, ahhhhh. As with all cities this old there was a hunt for food that I could access. It is there but our budget was taking a hit, again, so we often visited bakeries, groceries and at in our room. We went 48 hours before our train trip to Munich. We then reported 20 minutes ahead of our train and off we went. We had a connecting train in Salzburg that we

missed because the staff in Vienna didn‚Äôt notify the Salzburg staff of the wheelchair. But we got on the next train even though they said all the wheelchair spaces were booked. We were ushered into a wheelchair space anyway and rode the rest of the way to Munich. ***I forgot to mention that we spent the last night in Motel One across the street from the train station. A wonderful choice for wheelchair users. Also reasonably priced. ***If you are ever in Vienna and the wheel breaks on your largest suitcase you can get it repaired at Taschendoktor, Stumpergasse 36, 1060 Wien, Austria. Ph +43 1 5978701. The
owner said it would take a week but when my husband said we were gone in 3 days he had it ready in 2 days. A 50 euro hit but much less than the cost of a new bag.

Last week, the Minneapolis- St. Paul International Airport, in conjunction with Delta Airlines, opened a new mock airplane cabin for people with cognitive, psychological and physical disabilities and for trainers of service animals in order to provide an experience of what it feels like to fly. The mock cabin is called the MSP Travel Confidently Education Center and is the latest part of the airport‚Äôs Navigating MSP program, which helps travelers with disabilities. Thanks to our partner Open Doors Organization in Chicago for sharing this great information! ODO is an active member of the MSP Travelers with Disabilities Advisory Committee. We‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on this
new mock airplane cabin- is this something that you would benefit from? Have you ever tried a mock cabin before? Photo credit: Open Doors Organization

Hello! We will be traveling to Orlando soon to get my son a service dog from Canine Companions. We are planning on dividing the trip in to 2 days. We are looking for an accessible hotel around Valdosta Georgia. Does anyone have any recommendations? Heather Hooper

Bed height has become a major stressor in my travel. Height of the bed used to never be an issue. My major concern was a flip down shower bench in the shower. I don‚Äôt travel a great deal so I‚Äôm not really sure when this happened. The last hotel I stayed at was a bad experience. I had sent a picture showing a yardstick and the 26" height of my home mattress and my knee right next to it while seated in my manual chair. When I arrived, hotel mattress was way too tall, had a very cushy top and some kind of side board frame that kept

me from getting right up next to the mattress to transfer‚Ä¶ NOT good. I called to have it lowered and they basically put the mattress on the floor. Again, NOT good. They finally ended up with the mattress on some type of plastic crates. Closer to right height but side rail and cushy top still made transfer very awkward and very stressful since I was traveling alone. Any hopes of getting a standardized height for beds?

PRIOR TO ARRIVAL There were multiple contact points prior to our arrival. I was booking 3 rooms for 3 families. At the suggestion of the reservation agent, I booked 3 individual rooms: a Spa Studio 1 king, a Spa Studio 2 queens and 1 bedroom Spa Villa Suite. I explained to the agent that for the Villa Suite I needed some handicap accommodations. Basically, I need a shower chair, adjustable shower & elevated toilet with grab bars. I called multiple times to confirm that these accommodations were doable. the room. No one mentioned stairs to get to the spa studios until about a week prior to our stay.

HANDICAP PARKING There was no handicap parking near our room. The curb to the parking area is not wheelchair or cane friendly. In order to avoid a dangerous fall, my husband had to leave me sitting in a wheelchair at the curb, & then drive onto the sidewalk to pick me up or let me out. When I inquired about a handicap space, no one seemed to have an answer. Training for the front desk & operators may be helpful. DISABLED ROOM After check in, they finally brought in a shower chair, but no shower mat. This is a huge fall risk for any guest. There are no

bars in the shower & the shower head does not come down. The toilet riser was very loose & unsafe to use, & was delivered late. If you sat down the item would move out of place. This is a massive fall hazard. When I made the reservation I explained exactly what I needed in a hotel room; bars by the toilet, raised toilet, a portable shower chair, bars in the shower, but not necessarily an ADA room. We had to wait for shower mats, shower chair and toilet riser with arms. DANGEROUS GROUNDS The property is not handicap friendly! Or even safe for a disabled person. The

property is very poorly lit & there are many areas with over grown brush & uneven pavement that made it difficult & dangerous to maneuver with a wheelchair or cane. There were multiple areas where a wheelchair could not get by. I sent this in writing to the Director, it is now 9 months later and he has yet to contact me. He keeps saying he wants to connect with me. Any of these areas of concern are fixable I let him know that I preferred to settle the situation directly with the property rather than write a totally negative review. He obviously does not care his guest's
safety.

My husband and I were taking a quick trip to Washing DC over Labor Day. We decided to try a more central hotel than our usual. I found The Sofitel at a great rate through accessibleGO. When I went to book it the wheelchair accessible room was already booked up. Being a nice hotel I figured a regular room would do. Thanks to Patch for going above and beyond I got into the wheelchair accessible room. I have to say in all my travels I have never seen a truly luxury accessible room until now. I messed up my camera so no pictures. There was enough room to

get in, turn, park the chair for recharging. A nice loveseat area to relax. The bathroom was one to dream about. There was a bathtub with all of the rails and such. I couldn‚Äôt use it but hubby had a good hot soak. There were 2, yes 2 showers! Mine was a spacious roll-in with adjustable shower heights and hand held fixtures. The other was a standard with all the same fixtures and a rainfall showerhead. Check in was fast and super friendly. The attached restaurant was very nice. One of our favorite things was the valet service. Such a classy, professional and happy group. To haul my

wheelchairs we have a very large truck. When we drove in the valet said that they couldn‚Äôt park it in the garage as it was too big. These guys kept it parked out on the street. They moved it around as needed and we had constant access to it. It wasn‚Äôt cheap but worth every penny. The Sofitel is very close to the White House, restaurants galore, theaters.

Hi - my family and I are planning a trip to Barcelona in September. I can walk very short distances but otherwise use a foldable powered wheelchair. I just did 2 rooms, same hotel, same beds, one handicap and one not. Mine is $10 more. Frustrating.

The train ride from Interlaken, Switzerland to Milan was fast and efficient. We wanted a certain route but they told us at the station that that train was not suited for wheelchairs. So we went back through Zurich and down to Milan. The thing I noticed about the trains in Italy were that they were mostly lower. The helper at the station would carry a roll-up ramp and lay it down to cover the gap. If I could add to my luggage pile, without losing a husband, I would love one of my own. Milan is a big city. This was our splurge stopover. We used the Hotel

Korner Duomo. It was beautiful. It had the biggest pain in the behind elevator I have ever seen. But the room made up for it. We were literally around the corner from the Galleria and Duomo. We walked across to the Monument Cemetery which was jaw dropping. We did little but wander the streets oooing and ahhhing. We found a little restaurant near the Galleria(Marinos) and ate there every day. They treated us like neighbors. On my birthday (even planners can screw up now and then) we took the train to the Malpensa Airport for the night. We flew to Madrid the next day. Cobblestones are a real
pain when in a chair. But I loved all the marble walkways in the shopping areas.

Alaska is the last frontier, a wild, cold and crazy place with huge animals and insane weather‚ÄìBut it is also where I am from. It‚Äôs my home, and it is a large wild home, where exploration is a must, and the outdoors is part of life. Alaska is also concealed from the rest of the world. Blocked off by miles of ocean unless you want to drive for 4 days through Canada. Travel has to be by flight, and when you‚Äôre going to fly for 6 hours to get anywhere else, you might as well fly for 12 hours. So when I travel the world, I go far‚Äìto

the warmest, most adventurous places I can find. Ôªø Ôªø I‚Äôm Andrew Kurka, an Alaskan and an Athlete on the US Paralympic Ski Team. I also like to think of myself as somewhat of an explorer. An explorer that is always looking for new and better ways to travel. Being an Alaskan, everyday life isn‚Äôt the most accessible. So I found ways, to adapt, to overcome, to continue doing the things I love to do. The hardest part was accepting my differences and my disability, realizing that I could do anything, I just had to do it differently. Then finding those that would support me in those endeavors..

The world isn‚Äôt built for us, and adapting can be hard. The more streamlined the better. That‚Äôs why I am excited to join the accessibleGO team. accessibleGO helps those who are freshly disabled or have had lifelong disabilities, travel with confidence and enjoy themselves on the GO, wherever that may be. Ôªø Ôªø I broke my back when I was 13 in an ATV accident. Prior to the injury I was a wrestler and avid outdoorsman, a hunter, a fisherman. But the things I miss the most about having legs that work, was the freedom, the freedom of being able to just walk outside and GO. Hike this

hill, or ski that mountain. When my legs were taken from me, so was a portion of my life, and a portion of my identity. The athlete that was an awesome wrestler, the boy that would bike miles just to find a fishing spot. That person felt taken. For years I had tied my identity to the person who was built around these things, and then they were taken away. I struggled for two years, a young man lost. Alaska isn‚Äôt built for the disabled, we have pretty typical ADA standards but they aren‚Äôt typically met, especially in the winter time. Alaska, it‚Äôs wild! It‚Äôs the outdoors, and

the outdoors isn‚Äôt built for us. It‚Äôs the best part about Alaska, but also the hardest part of being disabled. I struggled with these facts, trying to accept the things I loved. Ôªø Ôªø Then, when I was 15, I was nominated to be the Children‚Äôs Miracle Network Spokesman for Alaska. I traveled and met lots of other children with disabilities, learned their life stories and was inspired. I met a young man with terminal cancer who especially changed my life. He was 7 years old, but wanted to see and experience everything. He didn‚Äôt know how much time he had left, and he was completely aware of

that fact. He just looked death in the eyes as if to say, ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôre coming for me, but I‚Äôll make you work for it.‚Äù He was mature for his age, which was scary for me. I was 15, but he seemed like more of an adult. But he also didn‚Äôt have any fear, after all what did he have to lose? What did he do to deserve this? Nothing, but he was determined to at least give it his best shot at the life he was given. After meeting this young man, I sat down, and thought about my life. What was I even doing here?

Why was I worried about who I used to be, why was I worried about my legs? Why was I sulking in the thoughts of the person I used to be? Instead of living the life of a fearless human that strives to at least experience what he can, while he can. That was when I started trying new things. Instead of focusing on the things that I used to do. I said, what can I do now? Or how can I do this? I started adapting, and in the process. I started living, I started skiing, I started playing hockey, I even started wrestling again. I started

fishing, kayaking, hunting, canoeing. I started living life, I began my journey molding my life to my dreams. Seeking the experiences of a lifetime. Though they were done differently, I still did them. I pursued experiences in life and in the outdoors, in every way I could, hoping that it would one day provide me with the means of helping others, like that young man helped me. Ôªø Ôªø Today I own a Bed and Breakfast in Alaska, with multiple ADA accessible cabins, nested on an airstrip. I am working toward finishing my pilot license, I own a saltwater fishing vessel and have adapted my life to what

I enjoy. I figured out how to do things with a disability. I am setting my life up so that I can do adventure camps, sharing that mindset and that freedom I have acquired with others. Ôªø Ôªø Andrew with his wife.While I still travel the world on the US Paralympic Ski Team, I am constantly learning to adapt to new situations and travel experiences. I know nothing is perfect but finding the best way to make things work is what I live for. Life will never be easy, but I‚Äôll always remain willing to work hard and try. I have had a successful career as a skier.

I have received a few paralympic medals and I have been crowned one of the fastest in the world. Yet I continue to pursue another Gold at the Paralympic Games while giving my all, to my business and my life. My journeys haven‚Äôt been without consequences, I have broken over 20 bones in my 31 years. But I will continue to push forward, living a fearless life and I hope you will too, in your own way.Ôªø Ôªø This is who I am, it is my life, my goals and my dreams. It is the reason why accessibleGO and I have decided to create a partnership. So that

we may help to inspire others. So that we can help answer questions that people may be unsure about. We can help make people with disabilities more comfortable away from home. So I can be an example and show you what I have made possible in my life. So that you may also do the same in yours. AccessibleGO can help people realize their possibilities and make those goals easier for them. Not to hold your hand, but to simply help you live the life you‚Äôve dreamed of, filled with experiences, travel, and fun. Those objectives are what we partnered over. The fact that I live and experience

everything I can, and we want that to be possible and comfortable for anyone with a disability. Sometimes it‚Äôs all about making one person smile, helping them to do that one thing they never thought they would experience again. Or at least giving them that opportunity. Because we should all strive to live and not to merely exist.

Book your next trip with us.

(Advisory: Although this tour is willing to work with people of all abilities, it is still necessary for safety reasons that participants have strong grip capabilities with hands and arms, no neck issues, and strong swimming skills.) A few years ago when Covid restrictions first started to lift, I grabbed my husband and caught the first flight to Sint Maarten Island that we could get on. When we arrived, we practically had the island to ourselves when it came to tourists and found that tour guides were more than willing to work with me and my physical disabilities since they didn‚Äôt have to focus on large tour groups.

However the one tour I wasn‚Äôt able to convince to work with me, was the new tours being offered using Sea Bob‚Äôs. (For people who are unfamiliar with what Sea Bob‚Äôs are, imagine a hand held jet ski engine that allows divers and snorkelers to fly over or under the water‚Äôs surface at speeds that match. Here is a link with more information.) You can‚Äôt imagine how angry that made me. My biggest pet peeve is when people make assumptions about what we are capable of. That is something we like to determine for ourselves. So when we got home, I started working on planning our next set

of excursions for an upcoming cruise we had booked that was going to be stopping in Aruba. Usually when we visit Aruba just for a day, I always book us on a Motorcycle-Trike* tour that also loves to work with people of all abilities (that is another review I am working on); but I noticed a company, SeaBob Aruba, also offering SeaBob tours and I thought I would make my pitch to them to see about including me in the tour. Not only were they willing to work with me, they started explaining to me how they are very used to working with people of all abilities and

would love to have us on the tour. I was so excited, even though the tour was still 7 months away. The day finally arrived when we docked in Aruba and I had my dream day ahead of me; a motorcycle tour all morning and Sea Bob‚Äôs all afternoon. The tour company met us right outside the dock and arranged a safe spot for me to load into the car and they were able to fit my entire wheelchair in the back of the van. Lucky for us that we were the only two people booked for the afternoon and ended up with a private tour. After a

fast stop to pick up the trailer with the gear, we headed to the beach spot and our tour guides did a tutorial for us about how the equipment worked and how to use it safely in the water; while I worked to get my wetsuit gear on. Once I was ready, the incredibly strong tour guides lifted me up in their arms and carried me safely all the way to the water and carefully set me down and my husband joined us in the water. Once I am in the water I am a strong enough swimmer that I am ok without an aide; but my wetsuit

does keep me floating at the surface. We were given our Sea-Bob‚Äôs and offered some time to familiarize ourselves with using the devices in the shallower water. As soon as we gave the cue we were feeling good with it, we headed out towards the sunken ship off-shore. On the way out, I took the chance to use the device under the water at top speeds and felt like Aquaman soaring under the water. The only downside was you can only stay under the water for as long as your breath lasts because we weren‚Äôt using any breathing apparatus. However this device is also used by scuba divers,

so they can be used underwater for extended times if you had the correct equipment. On the way out, the guides pointed out some large turtles under us and I was able to swim right over them. After a few minutes of soaring through the water, our tour guides informed us we had reached the ship. They did forget to mention what type of ship, so I was a little overwhelmed when you look down and see a sunken WWII German warship that was HUGE and cracked in half. Plus everything always looks bigger under the water with your mask on. Once I finally got used to looking

down at it, we took turns trying to fly down near it, but it was too deep for my husband and I to get too. Instead though, we were entertained by our tour guides who showed off their underwater superpowers and performed magic flying in and around the ship for the longest time. Was so cool watch and gave me fantasies of someday having that kind of breath control. When we were done exploring the ship, we headed back to an area more known for more large turtles and underwater sea life. This time when we spotted another giant turtle, I managed to swim right next to them

for quite awhile. When I started to realize they were not comfortable with the Sea Bobs, I backed off and gave it more space. As we got closer to the reefs, so many fish started showing up that I thought I was in a musical number from the Little Mermaid. I only wish I knew the names of what I was seeing to tell you what was down there, but it was AMAZING! Before I knew it, the time had expired and it was time to head back to the beach. It was so sad having to head back, because my adrenaline was pumping so high from getting

to experience all of that. Beyond how cool the Sea Bob experience was, there is something about accomplishing a task that someone else said you were incapable of that gives you this high about being alive and for just that brief moment in time, I have a feeling like I am capable of anything. These magical Seabob devices gave me the ability to reach areas above and under the water that I would have never been able to reach on my own due to my legs not kicking anymore‚Ä¶ so I was in love. Plus these tour guides never doubted me and let me try everything without any

hesitations, giving me that brief moment where I didn‚Äôt have to feel like I stood out with my disabilities. I wish I could explain how good of a feeling that is (to me at least), but as the guides carried me out of the water and back to the van to de-wetsuit; I was overwhelmed and didn‚Äôt know if I wanted to cry or just grin because I was so happy. They were just lucky it was too far for me to summersault back to the waters edge or I would have been back on that SeaBob for another lap around the bay. I forgot to mention that

they do offer a photo package that was very reasonable and then you get a ton of photos and movies sent to you digitally that is so much easier than trying to photograph yourself at the same time you‚Äôre trying to control the Bob. However it might be interesting to also attach your own go-pro strapped to your head for a first-person perspective, but I warn you that you go much faster than you can imagine under the water and not sure if it will stay attached? But definitely get the package because they capture all of the great moments with you in them, not just what you

saw happening. To me, this was the most perfect day of activities on an island I could fathom for myself. I got to fly above in the morning on the Trike; and then flew below with the Bob in the afternoon. There was so much adrenaline pumping that I was awake all night just glowing (don‚Äôt worry, it wasn‚Äôt a sunburn). Not only was the Sea Bob tour amazing itself, working with a company like SeaBob Aruba that understands that people with all types of physical abilities can do way more than we are ever given credit for; meant everything to me. The tour guides were phenomenal as

tour guides and as human beings. Felt like we had also made new friends that day too**. So now I have 2 things that I always HAVE to do when I get to Aruba, but I think the Sea-Bob‚Äôs have secured my #1 spot. **(And to help my tour guide who could not stop whistling a song he couldn‚Äôt remember the name or lyrics to; it was Scorpions doing ‚ÄúWind of Change.‚Äù I hope that helps?) üèç Trike Tour Review Coming soon üèç

Greetings - my gf and I will be traveling through South America for the last 3 weeks of April.
