However I believe this will be quite different because for all of that past travel, we‚Äôve always flown one of the major airlines here (American Airlines, Delta, United, Southwest, etc) and on these airlines the policy is pretty much the same across the board: I‚Äôm able to remain in my wheelchair

and check it right at the gate I‚Äôm allowed to bring a carry-on bag containing medical supplies in addition to whatever the standard cary-on allowance for that specific airline and class of ticket I‚Äôm allowed to carry on yet another bag containing my Freewheel (and its parts), which is essentially a 3rd wheel that attaches to my wheelchair allowing me to navigate some rougher terrain ‚Ä¶all this for no additional charge. I‚Äôm starting to get concerned as we look at flights between countries within South America (ex Ecuador to Argentina) and also flights with the same countries. What I‚Äôve been seeing is some pretty high costs for standard

carry-on as well as checked baggage and not much more information on what I‚Äôm allowed to bring (paid for or not) medical supplies/equipment-wise. Does anyone know if there is a standard policy in place of any sort with respect to this in South America? Anyone who has done any traveling in South America, any anecdotes to share that might give me an idea of what to expect? Or other tips?

My granddaughter is getting married in a few weeks. She and her future hubs reserved a block of rooms at the Marriott Detroit at the Renaissance Center. When they arranged for the rooms, they provided their contact person with our specific needs, i.e. a mobility handicapped room for one person (son, 34) with a connecting or adjoining room for 2, so we can assist our son as needed. The reservations clerk took note of the wedding party and seemed very competent. When I received email confirmation after the rooms were booked, the following note was at the bottom of the confirmation page: ‚ÄúDetroit Marriott at the Renaissance Center

will make every effort to accommodate the below requests, however they are not guaranteed. HANDICAPPED; C1‚Äù The hotel front desk refuses to discuss, saying I must use the 800# for reservations. The reservations people say they are powerless to guarantee the handicapped room. My granddaughter has reached out to her contact person who set up the block of rooms, but has been ghosted for over a week. We are only planning to stay one night, so my son can survive an overnight without a shower. What is not negotiable is the installation of grab bars at the toilet, as he is unable to transfer without them. The lack

of a guaranteed handicapped room puts us in an impossible situation. I can still cancel our reservation, and find another hotel, or we can drive home several hours late at night in unpredictable early March weather, following a long and very busy and tiring day. Has anyone else had this experience with hotel reservations? It seems like a violation of ADA. I am trying not to go nuclear for my granddaughter‚Äôs sake, but I am maddened by this policy and the inability to reach anyone at the hotel in a position to effect change. Does anyone have advice on how to handle this situation?

I‚Äôm a longtime Marriott member. However, their website is unfriendly to people with disabilities. One can‚Äôt reserve a guaranteed accessible room on the site. One can‚Äôt view whether an accessible room is available. You can‚Äôt request such a room until you‚Äôve picked a room type from a list of all rooms (not knowing whether that type actually has an accessible room.). Then your reservation summary says accessible room is a non-guaranteed request. So I guess After a flight one is supposed to just show up at the hotel in a wheelchair and hope they have a room. Shameful.

We had been to Munich years ago so were a little familiar with it. We booked the Eurostar Book Hotel. It was very close to the main train station. We had an accessible room and it met all the needs we usually look for. I will say Europe in general knows how to do wheelchair accessible bathrooms. The one draw back of the hotel was the front door. It was one big twirling entrance. They really should make an accessible door to the side. I let them know that. Munich was packed. It is Christmas Market season and it was crowded. We have learned that if I want

to see more then other peoples legs and backsides we have to visit the markets during the week days. Not as pretty without all the twinkly lights but easier on my nerves. I was proud of myself for not running over too many people, but the urge was real. A person (usually female and young) would look right at me as I was moving through the crowd and then step right into my path and stop. I resisted the urge but it was difficult. On our last day in Munich we were out wandering. A block from our hotel I went to cross the road, yes the pedestrian

light was green, and an impatient driver decided that he should have the right of way. Thank goodness my wheelchair is very sturdy. I took a broadside hit from the idiot. My chair stayed upright and I made sure my arms were inside so the injuries were limited. I heard the gasp of the onlookers but not one came to help. So important note **make sure you buy a sturdy wheelchair. Munich was very easy to get around and the public transit is all wheelchair accessible. The helper to get me on the train was very efficient. Our journey had us making a train change in Zurich. Per

usual our train was late and we had a 2 hour delay for another train. But the helper there took our bags and stored them for us for free. He gave us coupons to get a coffee or snack on the train too. I would love to come back to Zurich one day if our budget can handle it. Our next destination is Interlaken, Switzerland for Christmas.

accessibleGO is spotlighting accessibility-related companies who offer services and resources that serve our community. Today, we feature RightHear , an app that helps visually-impaired people navigate any environment. Introduce yourself and your company: Idan Meir is the Co-founder and CEO of RightHear, an innovative startup on a mission to turn public spaces into accessible environments for people with spatial orientation challenges, including people who are blind or visually impaired. Idan is originally from Israel but relocated with his family to Rockville, Maryland in 2021. Idan holds a bachelor‚Äôs degree in Psychology and Business from The Open University of Israel. He loves building companies, running, and eating hummus. Not

necessarily in that order. RightHear provides real-time audio descriptions to help the blind interpret and understand their surroundings. They have a free app on iOS and Android, over 2,500 accessible locations worldwide, and an ever-growing user base and community. RightHear has partnered with leading international brands like McDonalds, Microsoft, and Costa Coffee to improve accessibility compliance as well as promote inclusion. Here is a video of the app in action. How did the idea for this company come about? It happened almost by accident. Along with my partner, Gil Elgrably, we had created a technology to offer virtual on-the-spot coupons to shoppers based on Apple‚Äôs iBeacon technology. iBeacons

are small self-powered Bluetooth transmitters that can be placed on walls and roofs in a retail location. But the business model wasn‚Äôt making sense. We needed to build a very large user base for this to work and that was turning into a very large challenge. Then, during a 24-hour hackathon sponsored by the Ra‚Äôanana municipality, the Tel Aviv suburb in which RightHear is based, we had an insight. Rather than marketing the app to end users, what if we pitched it to the venues as a way of making their space accessible to people with visual impairment? We didn‚Äôt even know if blind people used smartphones or

apps since they‚Äôre so visual, but we put together a prototype in the hackathon and, the next day, the Ra‚Äôanana municipality connected us with several blind people in the city. They were blown away, they were so excited about it, even though we didn‚Äôt have a product yet. And RightHear was born! What accessibility challenges does your company help users over come? RightHear mimics the function of a venue‚Äôs directory board, whether that‚Äôs a sign reading ‚ÄúMacy‚Äôs this way, restrooms that way‚Äù in a mall, or orienting a visitor inside a university‚Äôs administration building. When users with the RightHear app on their phone approach the virtual sign, the

app speaks to them about what‚Äôs nearby. For example: ‚ÄúThe admissions office is 100 feet ahead to the right. Hours are 9:00am to 5:00pm, Monday through Friday‚Äù or ‚ÄúRestrooms 50 feet to the left.‚Äù Any memorable stories from your community that you'd like to share? A person that your product particularly impacted? You know, we've got this user, Hani. She's one of those people who you just can't forget. One day, she was heading home with her guide dog, but something went off. Her dog got lost, couldn't find their usual way home. Can you imagine the stress? So there she was, a little lost, a little unsure.

But then, she remembered RightHear was on her phone. She fired it up, and our app guided her safely back home. It's pretty wild when you think about it, right? A simple app turning a moment of anxiety into one of empowerment Ever since that day, Hani and RightHear, we're like best friends. She takes us everywhere she goes, and I mean everywhere - even when she's traveling abroad. New city, new country, new everything, but there's RightHear, helping her find her way, keeping her independent. When you get a story like Hani's, it hits you. It's not just about building a product. It's about changing lives, making

people feel more in control, more confident. And that, that's the real magic of what we do at RightHear. Why does accessibility matter to you? I believe that everyone should feel able, included, and empowered everywhere. Therefore, our aim at RightHear is to make the world a more accessible place for everyone. At RightHear, when we say universal access, we mean universal access. Our beacon technology removes physical barriers to access. But that‚Äôs not enough ‚Äì we also want to remove financial barriers to access. This is why our app on iOS and Android is 100% free to users today, and always will be free, it is vital

to us to ensure that the benefit of accessibility and independence for users should not come at a cost. What are some of your other favorite accessibility startups in the field right now? You know, we're living in an exciting time. All around us, startups are using technology to break down barriers and build a more inclusive world. It's inspiring, really, to see how much of an impact we're collectively making. Let me share a few of my favorites: First up, we've got OKO by Ayes . These guys are doing something pretty cool. Their app is all about making intersections easier to navigate for blind folks. Just

point your phone's back camera at a crossing, and voila, the app picks up the pedestrian signal. A simple concept, but it's really changing the game for people. Next, we've got Lotus Labs . They're taking things up a notch with a wearable ring. No, not like a magic ring, but close enough. You just point with the ring, and you can control stuff at home. It's almost like they're turning us into superheroes, right? And then there's ReBokeh . This one's a bit different, it's for people with moderate vision impairment. The app lets you create custom video filters based on your unique needs and environment. Think

of it like adjusting the world's focus to suit your eyesight. It's innovative, personalized, and just plain cool. Each of these startups is challenging the status quo, pushing boundaries, and reshaping how we think about accessibility. And that's the beauty of it all, right? It's not just about building products; it's about making a difference, one innovation at a time. We're not just in the business of accessibility, we're in the business of empowerment. How does somebody access & get started using RightHear? Users can simply download the app on iOS here and Android here . It‚Äôs free to download and use, we don‚Äôt even require a sign

up or login, we collect no personal information on our users. For businesses and venues, we offer a quick and simple solution that allows then to ensure that their buildings are accessible to all people, including those who are blind or visually impaired. We work with companies from local stores and restaurants, museums, hospitals, airports, all the way up to governments, global companies such as Microsoft, McDonalds and others.
